ALBANY, GEORGIA

i

\

`The World's Pecan Center

s\

Albany, a city of about 20,000 population is the commercial metropolis of

Southwest Georgia. Albany, has a Commission-City Manager form of Govern ment. Albany owns its water, light and gas plants; owns and operates a Munici pal Abattoir, and owns a Municipal Auditorium, seating 1800 people.

\

\s

Hydro-Electric Development

\

The South Georgia Power Company at Albany has two Hydro-Electric plants --one of 2,500 H. P., on Kinchafoonee Creek and one of 12,500 H. P., on Flint River. This Hydro-Electric Development makes it possible for the South Georgia

s\

Power Company to make very attractive wholesale power rates.

Health and Sanitation

s

Albany's water supply comes entirely from Artesion Wells. The quality of \

the water, the rigid sanitary regulations, the restrictions thrown around all milk and food supplies, combined with the wonderful climate, account for Albany's ex

\

ceptional health record.

\

S

\ Amusements

Albany is the Amusement center of Southwest Georgia. Radium Springs, is

a resort par excellence. Sport at Radium Springs includes golfing, on the champ \

ionship 18-hole course, trap shooting, swimming canoeing, fishing- and hunting. \

The Kinchafoonee Club has a splendid 9-hole golf course. There are four Muni

cipal Parks, with children's play grounds, tennis courts, etc. Good roads and the fine climate make motoring- an all year pursuit.

\

\

\ Railroad Facilities \ Albany, is served by seven lines of railroads, operated by The Central of

Georgia, Atlantic Coast Line, The Seaboard Air Line, Georgia South Western &

Gulf, and The Georgia Northern Railroads. The Central of Georgia and The At

lantic Coast Line Railroads are spending hundreds of thousands of dollars en

larging their terminal and shop facilities .at Albany. The completion of the At

lantic Coast Line's direct line from Albany to Tampa, Florida, has made Albany the Railroad gateway to Western Florida. It is now the second Freight terminus of the Atlantic Co.ast Line Railroad, ranking next to Richmond, Virginia, handling

\\

s a heavy movement of freight between Florida and the Central West. Excellent Passeng-er Service is available into and out of Albany. There are

six DeLuxe Passeng'er trains being operated daily to Cincinnati, Detroit, Cleveland, \

Chicago, and other important cities.

{

Agriculture and Pecan Industry

\

\ Albany is the World's Pecan Center. Forty-two per cent of the pecans grown

in Georgia are grown in Dougherty County and seventy-two per cent of the bear

i ing pecans in Georgia are within a radius of 60 miles of Albany. Pecans have be \

come one of the leading features of Southwest Georgia's Diversified Agriculture.

s Approximately five million pounds of pecans are handled throug'h the Albany

markets annually.

i

\

Albany's Industrial Development is based on the local supply of raw material

4s \

8

ADVERTISERS' SPECIAL DIRECTORY

\sss

PREFACE -- Albany, Georgia

\s

and upon the distribution facilities. Albany hats a cotton mill, a large hardwood mill, three pe.anut shelling plants,

six fertilizer factories, a cotton seed oil mill, gins, processing plants for pecans,

ss ss\

\

and numerous smaller industries. ,

Schools

Albany has just completed a $250,000 High School building, one of the model

High schools in the South. Albany has five grade grammar schools for white children and three for colored children, and a new high school for colored children also, the Georgia Normal and Industrial College, a State Institution for colored

pupils.

Good Roads

Albany is located on the Appalachian Scenic Highway, the Florida Short Route

ss

and the Western leg of the Dixie Highway. All three of these are popular motor

routes from North to South.

Excellent Churches

Albany has three Methodist Churches, two Baptist Churches, a Presbyterian

Church, an Episcopal Church, a Catholic Church and a Jewish Synagogue. The communicants of the various denominations dwell together in amity. No spirit of

intolerance is ever evidenced.

Climate

Albany is built on a level plateau on the west bank of the Flint River at

the head of Navigation. Its altitude above sea level is 212 feet. ``The climate of Southwest Georgia, in which Dougherty County is located, is

characterized by long, warm summers and short, mild winters. The summer

weather usually begins the latter part of March and continues until late October or early November. The mean temperature for this part of the year ranges from

about 60 degrees F. for the months of March and November to slightly above 80

degrees F. for the summer months, June, July and August. The hottest of these

months, July, has a mean temperature of 82.9 degrees F."
